xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This work is supported by Rachadapisak Sompote Fund for Postdoctoral Fellowship, Chulalongkorn University, and the University of South Carolina. Q.W. and Y.L. would like to thank the financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Programs 21429401, 21374119). The authors gratefully thank Dr. Soumitra Ghoshroy for EM analysis, as well as Dr. Pongkwan Sitasuwan for constructive discussions.

organization.$: Department of Food and Pharmaceutical Chemistry
State Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry

head.citation-title: Promotion of in Vitro Chondrogenesis of Mesenchymal Stem Cells Using in Situ Hyaluronic Hydrogel Functionalized with Rod-Like Viral Nanoparticles
head.abstracts: © 2016 American Chemical Society.This study focuses on the development of injectable hydrogels to mimic the cartilage microenvironment using hyaluronic acid (HA) derivatives as starting materials. Cysteine-inserted Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) mutants (TMV1cys) could be cross-linked to methacrylated hyaluronic acid (MeHA) polymers by thiol-ene "click" chemistry and form hydrogels under physiological condition. The resulting hydrogels could promote in vitro chondrogenesis of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) significantly higher than that in the TMV-free HA hydrogels by upregulating bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) expression and enhancing collagen accumulation.

organization.$: Department of Food and Pharmaceutical Chemistry

coredata.dc:description: This study focuses on the development of injectable hydrogels to mimic the cartilage microenvironment using hyaluronic acid (HA) derivatives as starting materials. Cysteine-inserted Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) mutants (TMV1cys) could be cross-linked to methacrylated hyaluronic acid (MeHA) polymers by thiol-ene "click" chemistry and form hydrogels under physiological condition. The resulting hydrogels could promote in vitro chondrogenesis of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) significantly higher than that in the TMV-free HA hydrogels by upregulating bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) expression and enhancing collagen accumulation.
coredata.dc:title: Promotion of in Vitro Chondrogenesis of Mesenchymal Stem Cells Using in Situ Hyaluronic Hydrogel Functionalized with Rod-Like Viral Nanoparticles
